title: Carbon Dioxide: An Open Door Policy
summary:
Key ideas
- Indoor carbon dioxide levels can have a significant effect on cognitive ability and sleep quality.
- CO2 levels are typically much worse at night when the windows and doors are closed.
- Human exhalation is the main source of CO2, and buildings with many people in close proximity are the most concerning.
- Plants that participate in "dark fixation" can help to reduce CO2 levels in a room.

Key learnings
- Increasing CO2 concentration from the level of a well-ventilated building to the level of a poorly-ventilated building had profound effects on cognitive ability.
- Workers in the best-ventilated offices scored about 25% better on cognitive tests than in the worst-ventilated ones.
- High physiological levels of carbon dioxide can cause sleep disturbances, and reducing CO2 levels can lead to improved sleep quality and cognitive performance.

Key questions
- How can we ensure that buildings are properly ventilated to maintain healthy levels of CO2?
- What are the long-term effects of exposure to high levels of carbon dioxide?
- How can we better understand the individual variability in sensitivity to CO2 levels?
